Actually I've learned Japanese for a year and a half. I should probably clarify how the course structure is laid out. There are two semesters once a year, and during semester 1 last year I did Japanese #65297;A, which was the introductory course to Japanese. Japanese #65297;B was in semester 2 last year, and I stopped at Japanese 2A, which was last semester this year. #12288;Japanese 2B would be this semester but I've stopped taking it. I've actually asked my lecturer what level of Japanese are we supposed to be at, and she said something along the lines of elementary students.

It's a beautiful game in terms of art. Different swords kind of have different movesets and attack patterns/speed, and they each have a distinct special move. The combat is quite fun, its quite fluid and fast paced. The boss fights are great too, and there are survival-esque dungeons that allow replayability etc. A few gripes I have though is the constant backtracking you have to do. The whole game is structured like running from point A to point B through the same environment to fight a boss, and on the way there there's multiple branching paths. After that, you have to backtrack the way you came from to do something else. The game has a fast travel system that you can access, but it isn't constantly available to you...so most of the time you spend not fighting is spent running back and forth. Exploration does get quite tiresome at times. I wasn't really fond of the music either, it gets really droning when you're just running through the environment. But really, everything else is pretty damn good, the combat, story, and the art makes up for a lot of it. Also the food and cooking system in this game is bloody amazing. It just looks gorgeous.

My family moved into this new neighbourhood a few years back. It's a gated community, and everyone there were pretty welcoming. Nice people in general, except this one neighbour that was on the left side of our house. This neighbour was a middle aged woman that lived with her daughter, who was around 19 or so iirc. I think she was divorced. When we first moved in, she seemed like a nice person, and she would occasionally interact with us and stuff. But after a few months, and I'm talking like within the first half year that we moved in, she became really nasty. I don't know what set her off, but I honestly doubt my parents did anything to instigate her, since we're a very quiet family. Now, the houses are connected by a wall, and its a pretty short wall too, short enough for someone to throw something over it and hit stuff on the other side. One day we woke up to a shattered kitchen window, and like rocks all around the garden and porch. We confronted her and she started accusing me that I threw rocks at her house first, but I seriously didn't do anything. She freaked out really badly, and the whole neighbourhood could hear her screaming her head off, and just ranting on and on about how we're a terrible family. Shortly after that, she poisoned all our fish. We had this small water feature installed at our side of the wall, and one day my dad woke up to a mini bubble bath in the garden, and all the fish dead in it. She probably threw soap or detergent into it, and since the water runs actively, it foamed and...yeah. It was pretty bad. After a few more screaming confrontations we called the cops (under the advice of other neighbours). Her daughter was actually quite nice, and would apologize to us and iirc, explain that her mother had some mental issues to deal with. No idea whether it was true or not. It calmed down for a few months, and then she moved out shortly after that. tl;dr: neighbour lady threw rocks at our house and poisoned our koi fish

Estival is the sequel to Shinovi. Haven't played Estival, but it has more features like a kissing mode, diorama mode (taking pics of life and hometown) etc. Shinovi Versus introduces a new faction that also appears in Estival Versus, so its kind of connected in that sense. I don't think the plot is connected, even if it is its just loosely, its more of getting to know the characters that debuted in Shinovi, as they appear in Estival also. Shinovi is pretty good for a brawler, but it does get repetitive. You basically fight enemies in a small arena, move on, more fighting, then its boss time. Another gripe I have is that the feedback sometimes feel quite lacking, like when you're fighting and you just don't feel like you're hitting something. Could just be me though. Can't comment on Estival's gameplay because I don't own it yet, but it should be more or less the same... Endless Summer edition comes with a box, artbook, OST, and some cards. Sakura edition comes with extra DLC swimsuits, but seems like its PS4 and Japan only. If you want more features then you probably could just jump into Estival, but if you want continuity (not really) then you can start with Shinovi, its really up to you.

You need to understand that the largest market for the Vita currently is in Japan (don't quote me on this, but it's quite obvious). Japanese developers make games like these to cater towards the Japanese audience and culture. The few indie titles on the Vita are typically from a couple of Western developers. Anime (or according to you, "weeaboo games") games are inevitable because its something that appeals towards the Japanese audience, which happens to be the Vita's largest market. No sane company is stupid enough to start pumping out games for a market that won't bring about profit. According to you though, these are "weeaboo games" just because they're too...japanese-y? I feel like a weeaboo game is more like a game that's been developed by a western developer that just wants to add a ton of Japanese culture and references into their game without actually knowing what the actual context is. These games were developed by actual Japanese people, and then translated by publishers and brought over here, so weaaboo kind of doesn't apply to them since they were originally Japanese... Also not sure why you're trash talking the Vita on a subreddit that's dedicated for the Vita, but okay...just because the thing doesn't cater to your personal preferences doesn't mean it's bad. Judging on your comments though, you're better off just selling it.

You might have to hunt around for shops like these, maybe? EB Games and JB Hi-Fi here has completely obliterated the Vita section too. Other than that I just buy it off PSN. Oreshika: Tainted Bloodlines is one hell of a JRPG. The aesthetics of the game is fantastic, and the gameplay is great. While not technically a JRPG, Valkyria Chronicles 2 (PSP) is fun as hell too.

They're completely different. In Oreshika you have your standard dungeon crawling where you have to look for this room that transports you to like Hell where you fight a boss. There's also a timer to dungeon crawling, so overall its much more fast paced than P4G's dungeons. The combat system is also based on rows, and not individual turns. You also have a village to like manage, where you can upgrade shops to get better goods, have festivals, and invite merchants or smiths to get better equipment. The breeding mechanic is quite confusing at first, but basically you have to collect points from dungeon crawling that allows you to mate with gods. Weak gods require less points, and the offspring will of course be weak, and stronger ones will need more points. Different gods also have different elemental affinity. I think there's like fire, water, wind and earth. I haven't quite figured it out yet, but if your character has a high fire element stat, and if you match it with a similar fire god, the kid will have a higher chance to unlock some fire based secret art. The breeding system also acts like a time limit system in a way. Your characters have a certain lifespan to them, and you have to consistently mate to ensure your bloodline continues.

Gamefaqs should have P4G walkthroughs. Dont think theres any difference between a easy and normal walkthrough. My advice though, as its your first Persona game, you're better off not following a guide and enjoy the game as it is. Do a NG+ after that and follow a guide then to 100% the game. If you follow a guide, you have to stick to it really strictly as the schedule is really tight, and IMO it detracts the overall enjoyment of a first playthrough, considering its a plot heavy game.

It's pretty basic for a rhythm game. I enjoyed it largely for its visuals, the animations and choreography are an absolute thrill to look at, but it's definitely a game aimed at Persona fans. The game has some really good remixes, but it's still a relatively small tracklist compared to other rhythm games. There's a few DLC songs that were really really good too. The story...well it IS a spin-off of a JRPG with a really good plot, but IMO it's not that great, but not very bad either, it's just okay. Maybe because I was expecting it to live up more to its parent game plot.

I don't think missing some items in early game will affect a lot. I guess it's still down to how you want to play it. For me, I played it blindly and patiently learned about how fusing Personas work, which and which made what combination etc, working out what I want to do next etc. I guess to me the first playthrough was to learn about the game and enjoy the story, and NG+ was just maxing out everything to 100%.

Yup. They're not connected, but still....yup. There's also the fact that P3P is older than P4G, and therefore less nice looking, so it might be hard to get into P3P after you play P4G, so play P3P first then P4G.

WRITING.TITLE: Estival Versus is really surprisingly good.
WRITING.TEXT: At first I thought it'll be pretty similar to Shinovi Vs, so I wasn't expecting much when I got into it. Nearing the end of the 4th school of SV, I was just sick of it because it felt like it was really dragging it's heels at that point, but wanted to just push through for some of the trophies. But when I played EV, it was surprisingly pleasant. **What's great:** There's a huge updated roster filled with different characters that have different movesets, the visuals are crisp and neat, the cutscenes, transitions, animations are really fluid, updated transformation scenes amp; character art, and the soundtrack imo is a huge upgrade from SV. The gameplay feels really solid and "grounded", compared to SV where it felt much more "floaty" to me. Characters with large heavy weapons feel heavy like they're supposed to, while characters that were supposed to be agile felt really good to control. There's also new mechanics like a wall ambush, environmental finishers, combo aerial raves, and throw-able bombs. Story wise, it really doesn't take itself seriously, but there are parts where it gets quite dark and emotional (as per usual) so you'll either love it or hate it. Performance wise, it's loading times are more or less the same as SV, but to have so many enemies with explodable clothing on screen, it plays really smoothly. **What's not that great:** Leveling up is much more slower compared to SV, where you would jump 4-5 levels after a stage, even with a low grade. In EV, it can take up to 2 stages for 1 level up. And because you need to reach a certain level to unlock more of your moves, it's quite tedious to be stuck with the same basic combos for quite a bit. EV also has a system where you have to unlock the girls' personal missions as well, based on this plot device, compared to SV where it was already available. Not a big fan of this. So yeah, my two cents on this game. Look beyond the butts and boobs and you'll find a pretty good action brawler, imo. Or maybe you just like butts and boobs. That's fine too.

It's pretty stable for the most part, no noticeable slowdowns for me even when you're in the thick of action. Starting here (Vita) is fine, but EV has characters that debuted in SV, and their backgrounds do carry over and are part of the story, so you might feel a bit lost at times.

In the personal missions of SV, I felt that it didn't really add more to their characters, but instead it was more of their wacky interactions/adventures with other girls instead...? Then again, I did the personal missions pretty early on, so I did get most of them decently leveled in the middle of the story mode, so maybe I'm a bit biased in that sense, haha. I guess it makes sense though, they would want you to play through the story to a decent point before letting you move on into other modes.
I don't remember any references but some of the remixed tracks also came from P4A/U...that's about it.
Still holding out hope for a Vita port...it still maybe probably possibly have a chance that it'll happen.

WRITING.TITLE: A cat and kitten snuggling under Hachiko's watchful eye at Shibuya Station.

WRITING.TEXT: Maybe you should cut out Hiroshima? Instead, spend more time in Tokyo, then activate your 7 days JR Pass on Day 6/7, so you can use your JR Pass when returning from Osaka back to Tokyo on Day 13. gt; Day 3 Tokyo Personally, for Day 3, I would go to Asakusa instead of the Tokyo Skytree. If you're after the paid (2000 yen!) observation deck of the Skytree, you can go to the Tokyo Government Metro Building (Tocho) in Shinjuku instead (on Day 2), as they have a free observation deck. On a clear day, you get a sweet view of Tokyo, and you might even see Mt Fuji in the distance if you're lucky (for free!). #160; So I would do Day 3 as such: Tsukiji gt;Asakusa gt;Akihabara (you can interchange Akiba and Asakusa since these 3 areas are really close by anyway). #160; For food, Tsukiji has some really really popular sushi places that's packed from early morning onwards, so it really depends on what you're after. I had my lunch by walking around the outer market and trying out a plethora of street food (eg uni, crab miso, various grilled skewers/shellfish), and then randomly picking a restaurant for a chirashidon. For Asakusa, there are restaurants along the side leading up to Sensoji. Asakusa is pretty popular for its tempura restaurants. For Akihabara, I went for [Kyushu Jangara Ramen] (https://goo.gl/maps/inJmqoEYod92) and [Marugo] (https://goo.gl/maps/ryjZh7qgjZ22). These 2 were freaking awesome. gt;Day 8 Kyoto This is a really packed day. The travel route makes sense, but you have to factor in travel time and time spent at these places. By the way, which area are you staying in Kyoto? Remember to check out Ninnenzaka/Sannenzaka for your dose of traditional Japanese houses, shops and scenery, which is around Kiyomizu-dera (just a heads up, they're renovating the main temple platform till 2020, so the iconic structure is covered by scaffolding. It's still worth going though.) gt;Day 9 Kyoto As CyanRaven mentioned, you **MUST** go to Fushimi Inari if it's your first time to Japan. I would suggest that you go to Inari early in the morning, spend a good 2-3 hours there, then head back to Kyoto for Nishiki Market, and then shopping. Most of Kyoto's shopping is concentrated around Teramachi-dori and Shin Kyogoku (it's preeetty tourist-y), which is right next to Nishiki anyway. Then Gion for the evening. Don't forget to check out Yasaka Shrine which is nearby. #160; This can't be overstated enough, but Japan is a freaking amazing place to travel to. Don't fret too much if you can't cover everything in your plan and have to cut out some places. Have a fantastic trip.

Hey dude, sorry about your experiences man. I can kinda relate, studied in Aus for a few years. Didn't make as much local friends as I would like to, but that's because I'm an introvert. WRITING.TITLE: Experts laud new police system tracking CP users

WRITING.TEXT: Important to note from the article is that, regular porn users is highly likely to not be monitored. gt; "Rozario said, however, that general Internet users should not be alarmed as police will not likely use the system to monitor regular Internet usage outside of P2P networks, amid perception that authorities would watch regular porn users. gt; #8220;The monitoring is limited to a small set of P2P networks like bit-torrent, Ares and Freenet. Your Facebook, Twitter, Google, Youtube and all other Internet traffic is still very much private, #8221; he said. gt; Cyber security expert Fong Chook Fook said mass surveillance was unlikely as it would incur a high cost on the government. gt; #8220;The authorities conduct targeted surveillance based on reports. The result of which led to arrests of perpetrators involved in online scams, gambling and such. Mass surveillance is just too resource-intensive, #8217; #8217; he added." Here's a [PPT] (https://www.google.com/url?sa=t amp;source=web amp;rct=j amp;url=http://www.teorieib.cz/pbi/files/103-Erdely_ICAC%2520Cops%2520P2P.pptx amp;ved=2ahUKEwjVtM3Th5bcAhWLfn0KHeLUBkgQFjABegQIBBAB amp;usg=AOvVaw23KDiNafMQ63iefk63LPqK) describing how the software actually works (credit: Keith Rozario Twitter) So if you stick to regular porn, don't freak out so quickly. NST seriously misleading and fearmongering with their article. Sure, authorities probably know that you watch regular porn. But there's too much traffic to actually realistically monitor. They aren't interested in seeing what y'all fap or shlick to lol. Only the absolutely terrible ones.

Multi level marketing. The "legal version" of a pyramid scheme lol. You obtain stock for a product from a MLM company. Now you need to sell this stock. So you recruit people. These idiots think MLM is good money, that's fine. Then these idiots that you recruited, they in turn recruit more bodo people. So it keeps going on. Lets say you recruit two people. Then your 2 recruits recruit 2 people each. Then they recruit 3 people each. So it forms a pyramid. Thats why its "multi level". Now, everyone has to sell this stock off. So every sale your recruits, and their recruits make, you get a commission. So that's how you "earn" in a MLM. There are some that pays based off how many ppl you manage to recruit. So the lower levels, your underlings, they earn like shit, while you sit on top and feed off their hard work.

OP, I'm in no position to advise or guide you on what you should do with your life, but giving up is not the way. WRITING.TITLE: Moving out from parents house as a Malaysian
WRITING.TEXT: Funny how my mother always threatens "if you so good, you move out la!" then when I actually bring up the idea to her with like a proper plan in place, she says "why you wanna move out, now you old already, you wanna dump your parents now la?". So I'm stuck in this constant limbo. Move out also wrong. Don't move out also wrong. It's so frustrating. At one hand, she asks me to grow up and be independent. On the other hand, she refuses to let go. Sometimes I wonder, how does the average Malaysian take that first step to move out from their parents house. How was it for you monyets? What age did ya'll move out from your parents houses? How did it happen? Any tips?
You're very helpful. Thank you for your valuable input.

It shouldn't be an issue. I'm financially capable to move out. I have a plan in place. The thing is, my parents take moving out as a declaration that "I want nothing to do with them, and I'm cutting off all familial connections with them". My mum would probably just disown me on the spot. I don't actually want that to happen. And well, I'm the only son in a traditional Chinese family. As per filial piety, it'll eventually be my responsibility to take care of my parents as they get older. And in my family, the only way of doing this is to stay with your parents to care for them. Moving out would be seen as an extremely rebellious and shitty move, causing my parents to lose face etc.

Look up Dr Ranjit at SS15, Subang Jaya. Reputable skin specialist. Unfortunately I don't take Accutane as I'm saving it as a "last resort" method (heard some ppl do experience side effects which worsens the acne), my condition isn't too bad atm as its mostly scarring for me. Anyway, doc prescribed me facial cleanser and two topical creams. Lasts about 3 months, costs about RM130 including consultation. My acne is mostly gone with the exception of 1 or 2 occassional popout. I'm guessing it should be roughly the same cost if you wanna jump on Accutane. Subsequent visits to the doc, you can just collect the medicine over the counter. So no consultation fees incurred there, just meds only. Best to see him first and get a proper diagnosis on your condition. The clinic is really popular and there's large crowds almost everyday, so make an appointment first. Last time I walk in, it took me about 4 hours to see him.

It hurts more to know that Matt and Pat aren't friends anymore, and I hope they reconcile in the future. Thank you so much and I wish nothing but the best to you guys Now someone please make a supercut of all the best moments of every single video they've done. I'd cry if it really happened.

Heavy Rain, Downcoming (both), Man vs Wild, Ride to Hell, TWD1, RE7, TEW2, Deadly Premonition, Disaster Day of Crisis, Yakuza 4, Predator Concrete Jungle, Barkley Gaiden are my favourite LPs. Every Shitstorm series is my fav as well. I still listen to these while in bed as it helps me fall asleep. Too many favourite moments to recount. Too many good memories, jokes and burns. But if I had to choose one, for me it's gotta be the infamous axe throw. Now I'm sad again.

When did it become a norm to post pictures of your family or yourself on the internet? I can't even bear to think how these pics get circulated or used...this kinda stuff should be left private. Its a competition at this point, a game of "My mom is hotter than your mom". Especially posting on a website like Reddit where its largely anons and strangers? You're gonna get fucking flak for it. People need to realize when you post pics of yourself or your family on the internet, you're putting yourself OUT there, for the whole world to view. And that shit can't be easily removed, even if you delete the pic or post - who knows what creep out there has it saved for "personal uses" or spreading it on another forum...
Remember kiddos, bad publicity is still publicity.

Worked in Inspidea (not as an Animator, but worked closely with them). Paid like shit, staff treated like shit (by clients and management), and their whole renumeration amp; incentive structure were abysmal. High af turnover rate, ppl kept going out and coming in, but I expect its like this in the industry. However, the projects they did were pretty interesting, and there was a lot to learn and gain experience from. Good for a stepping stone - definitely not long term, not any studio in Malaysia. Sadly that's the reality of the animation industry in Malaysia, and its not gonna change anytime soon. "Industry standard" they call it. But its just a convenient excuse to fuck over animators and related jobs.

WRITING.TITLE: Waved to a complete stranger twice
WRITING.TEXT: Just happened, I was in my company parking lot, entered my car to drive home, when I saw this man entering his car opposite to mine. As the basement parking is dimly lit I couldn't really make out his face but he resembled this work acquaintance of mine. The guy was smiling at my direction so I waved at him but he didn't respond. Then it hit me, oh shit, I don't know this guy...and somehow my mind doubled down and I waved AGAIN hoping he would respond...but he didn't. And I'm sure he saw me wave at him twice. This random dude just enthusiastically waving at him from inside his car. The guy just drove away but I'm sat here in my car, red faced, contemplating my life choices. How I wish my windshield was tinted darker right now...

No no no, it's easier to just lump everything related to China as bad and oppressive.

Yes, I ain't denying that. I agree with you, China's government is bad and oppressive. But it sure seems people just make these comments just for the hell of it even though there's no proof that Tencent has any say in Reddits operations or content other than just giving them funding. So why generalize? If anything, subreddit mods are the ones censoring posts and comments, not Tencent.

People may think I'm defending China, but no - I dislike the Chinese state government a lot too. However I just don't agree that broad blanket generalizations should be made. The assumptions that are made that all China people are as bad as their government will lead to even more prejudice and hatred. That's never a good thing.
